pr_title: Add token refresh options to simple token cache (azure-core) #12403

timeline.message: Add token refresh options to simple token cache
Merge branch 'simpletokencache' of github.com:jianghaolu/azure-sdk-for-java into simpletokencache

timeline.bodyText: Since this is on the TokenRefreshOptions should we remove the "TokenRefresh" from these property accessors? In this case getRetryTimeout
timeline.author: schaabs

timeline.bodyText: same as above, could this be just setOffset?
timeline.author: schaabs

timeline.bodyText: I think it's could be problematic to have setters for these properties. If TokenRefreshOptions is mutable TokenCredential implementations will have to copy this object to avoid mutations in behavior.  Is it possible to only take these arguments on construction? or would we need to add a builder to make this class immutable?
timeline.author: schaabs

replies.bodyText: I can move them to a constructor but then it will be difficult to add more options in the future. Most of the "XXXOptions" in the Java SDK today are mutable like AmqpRetryOptions, HttpLogOptions
replies.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText:
From the Java SDK authoring guidelines (https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/java_design.html#model-classes):

✅ DO provide public constructors for all model classes that a user is allowed to instantiate. Model classes that are not instantiable by the user, for example if they are model types returned from the service, should not have any publicly visible constructors.
Use a no-args constructor and a fluent setter API to configure the model class. However, other designs may be used for the constructor when appropriate.


⛔️ DO NOT offer a builder class for model classes.


✅ DO ensure that setter methods within a fluent type return the same instance of the type.
Fluent types must not be immutable. Don’t return a new instance on each setter call.
replies.author: jianghaolu

timeline.bodyText: I worry that this property is very complex  to use. TokenCredentialOptions already have retry options, and this adds another level of complexity to that. If we make it configurable users might have to understand the interrelated nature of this and the retry options. Perhaps we could defer allowing this to be configurable? If not I don't think that RetryTimeout really describes what this property is used for.
timeline.author: schaabs

replies.bodyText:
On IdentityClientOptions this is called tokenRefreshRetryTimeout(). The name is only simplified as you suggested in TokenRefreshOptions. I agreed to make the change considering this is in the context of the TokenRefreshOptions class.
For .NET if you already have a TokenCredentialsOptions it could make more sense to move this inside TokenCredentialOptions. It could live there as a RefreshOptions property bag, or flattened as RefreshTimeout and RefreshOffset properties.
replies.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText: On second thought, I'll make the case for this class to be immutable as an exception submitted to Java architects. That will make sure these are only modifiable from a subclass.
replies.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText: @schaabs Considering that in the current Java implementation, the timeout only applies to error retries, but also refreshes after a previous successful refresh, this may be better called "getTimeout()" in TokenRefreshOptions.java, or TokenRefreshTimeout in other places like TokenCredentialOptions.cs. The scenario happens if a user specifies a "tokenRefreshOffset" that's equal to or longer than the token valid time, it prevents the cache from proactive refreshing on every single request.
replies.author: jianghaolu

timeline.message: Merge branch 'release/azurecore-1.6.0-beta.1' of github.com:Azure/azure-sdk-for-java into simpletokencache
Merge branch 'release/azurecore-1.6.0-beta.1' of github.com:Azure/azure-sdk-for-java into simpletokencache
Remove tokenRefreshTimeout and add more javadocs
update tests with non-configurable token refresh timeout
